## Small property functions {.unnumbered}


### Description

<code>ndim()</code> returns the number of dimensions of an object. <br />
<code>lst.ndim()</code> returns the number of dimensions of every list-element. <br />
<code>lst.typeof()</code> returns the (internal) type of every list-element. <br />
<br />



### Usage

<pre><code class='language-R'>ndim(x)

lst.ndim(x)

lst.typeof(x)
</code></pre>


### Arguments

<table>
<tr><td style = "white-space: collapse; font-family: monospace; vertical-align: top"><code id="x">x</code></td>
<td>
an object.<br />
For functions starting with <code>lst.</code>, <code>x</code> must be a list (i.e. recursive vector or recursive array). <br />
</td></tr>
</table>


### Value

For <code>ndim()</code>: an integer scalar. <br />
For <code>lst.ndim()</code>: an integer vector, with the same length, names and dimensions as <code>x</code>. <br />
For <code>lst.typeof()</code>: a character vector, with the same length, names and dimensions as <code>x</code>. <br />



### Examples
```{r, warning=FALSE, message=FALSE, eval=TRUE, collapse = TRUE, comment = NA}
library("broadcast")


# matrix example ====
x <- list(
  array(1:10, 10),
  array(1:10, c(2, 5)),
  array(c(letters, NA), c(3,3,3))
)
lst.ndim(x)
lst.typeof(x)


```
